text: Thanks very much So hopefully I wasn't playing keyword bingo with the title of this talk and people are actually here and they like Python maybe they're touching kubernetes every day and they don't really like YAML You're in the right place But who am I I'm Elliot Gunton senior software engineer at PyKit We're a startup and I'm a hair and maintainer and more about that in a And quick plug for the company sponsoring my food and everything So we help you scale Argo and kubernetes so we're working with companies that get direct support from Argo workflows maintainers that saves you engineering time and compute costs So the outline for today what is kubernetes I hope people can kind of answer that question The K stands for kubernetes What is Argo workflows Maybe you've heard of it or you're And then we'll talk about all things Hera so focusing on the Python aspect with features and examples And hopefully a demo that goes smoothly and the takeaways for the talk today So what is kubernetes How I would describe it to someone who's not really technical I'd maybe skip the first line but it's the cloud native standard but it allows your applications to scale more easily It's container native It's got an active and growing community long term support vendor neutral all the boxes you want to tick when you're looking for software to run on And what is Argo workflows What's the difference The last four were the same It's built on kubernetes so you get all the same benefits And it's kind of won the adoption wars as well to become the de facto workflow orchestration standard for kubernetes And that means you're scaling workloads more easily in the same way you're scaling apps on kubernetes So why would you even need an Argo orchestrator It's a bit of a can do anything box of tricks that you need to use Maybe you have machine learning pipelines training pipelines you're collecting data training models deploying them It works for all kinds of data processing image processing video processing that kind of stuff and schedule jobs on that kind of cron schedule You'll need these kind of features if you're looking at kubernetes like scalable resources automatic retries and integrated artifact storage so you don't have to worry about I just made a thing How do I get it onto my storage over there Argo will handle that for you So diving into the anatomy of our workflow it's a kubernetes custom resource definition If you're using kubernetes you see these day in and day out It's a kind of workflow and then it has these templates which are analogous to functions in a So we have this diamond DAG and we have this echo container down here And these templates can be arranged through a DAG So we're arranging this echo container to be run four times through a DAG of tasks And this entry point up here diamond is kind of the main function of the workflow So the average Argo developer experiences that you've written a YAML of a thousand lines and you just bog down it's hard to test hard to reuse anything and you just kind of get fed up with pull requests that make no sense And you are thinking I'm in the wrong place why is he talking about YAML still Imagine if you work primarily in Python you think YAML is funky JSON You know some buzzwords about kubernetes like pods container cloud native and you need to run stuff on cloud native So this was me about three years ago at We wanted to get rid of airflow clusters and have people running on kubernetes So to get them on to kubernetes we needed something like Hera which is the Python SDK for Argo workflows so that people wouldn't have to interact with YAML day in day out So this lets you write your templates as functions orchestrate them and test them all in Python if you want You can interact with the Argo server API just through Python So it's just an API call And that gets you the best of both worlds So Python's got all these great things like developer experience libraries testing you get your code completion it's preferred scripting language for many people packaging and versioning And Argo we've got all those benefits of kubernetes that we mentioned earlier so we get resource management we get parallelized workloads and artifact storage integrations So Hera gives you a seamless all in one solution of the business logic is in your Python functions you have a workflow orchestration of those functions separate and you can even submit the workflows from Python And all that is nothing if you don't know how to use it so we've got extensive documentation we've got a walkthrough that takes you from zero knowledge through to submitting and using the more advanced features of and user guides for the super advanced features that need a bit more explanation that can fit in a walkthrough But that's enough talking let's see some code So we're going to take a YAML workflow that we just saw and we're going to turn it into Hera just like that But let's take this line by line It's making a DAG where we have the A B C and D obviously by the diagram But starting with these custom written classes these are not auto generated from the kubernetes spec these are handwritten that help you get your workflow running more easily So you get nice code completion things kind of make more sense And we have this context manager pattern if you use Python you get to use this with syntax and then that creates a new context And that kind of looks like the YAML dictionary format if you squint your eyes a So when you're reading documentation from both sources if they're using YAML or they're using Python you kind of can orient yourself So inside the context objects are added automatically The container goes into the workflow the tasks go into the DAG And we have a little bit of syntactic sugar sprinkled where on this line we're calling the container template and we're passing the keyword arguments that came from the task just now So we have named arguments that just save you some boilerplate And finally you're arranging the task dependencies with this right shift operator If you've used Airflow then it'll look familiar And a quick side by side if you still prefer the right you can leave the room now So container native is cool but what about Python native I was just talking about functions can be your templates but we're looking at this container so it's running an image command take some inputs But I just want to write Maybe I already have a function and I just want to run it on And with Herit all you need is the decorator that says this is the image I need run the code inside And the syntax inside the DAG is exactly the same so the only thing that's changed here is this function And once you have that workflow you need to maybe submit it to the Argo server That's just a w create on the end Once you've set up the namespace and the workflow service and let's say this is running on a local host then w create will get it right And once you've submitted it you can get an auto generated workflow object back You can convert it but in this example it's just using the model workflow You can see the name and the namespace You can just print some diagnostics if you want but basically open that and you'll see the workflow running So you'll see live progress You see the task details on the sidebar and you can go through per container logs So what we're looking at here is an inline script template So revealing the magic behind the curtain a bit it's not just give me an image It will take that image and it's running through it but here it adds a little bit of boilerplate to load some input parameters for you and your function will be pasted in basically This is exactly what you wrote But that comes with some So even if I said this is a string down here JSON load if you know how it it just takes whatever it sees and then gives you something out and Python is dynamically typed so this message could be an integer It could be a string Who We just trust the user at that point which is always a bad idea And when we're running on Kubernetes this is basically like running a Python file so there's no returns and what does this mean We can't really test this function We're just praying that it works So the Hera script runner is a feature of Hera which kind of solves this It lets you run actually native Python functions on Argo workplace and all you need is to build an image and then Argo will pull that and Hera runs that code through its module So what that means is you get these deserialized inputs They get type checked so if you try to pass a string as a length it says no no you're not allowed to do that and you can also return and that means you can test So you might be looking at this if you use Python every day just like bro what This is obvious But in the YAML world you can't really test templates individually When it's in a workflow you need to run the whole workflow on the cluster and say this ran in this order you set up the dependencies in that way Here we've got one script template being tested individually by itself which doesn't seem groundbreaking but in the Kubernetes world it kind of is So how do you set that up You just need two bits of input the constructor is a runner and the image is something that you're going to build so it's almost a chicken and egg problem but you write the you build from it and then you run it And if you've used Python for a bit you'll know about Pydantic This is a library that does basically API serialization JSON to Python and back And Hera already integrates with to get that type check validation at runtime that I showed you but you can take it a step further and get these custom structured input and and then Hera will automatically serialize and deserialize for the JSON objects So using Pydantic let's replace this length and very complicated business logic calculating the area of a with a rectangle class So what you need to start with is the rectangle class It's a subclass of BaseModel which comes from Pydantic and we're going to give it a function on that class And then simply changing the input here we're using the rectangle directly within the function and then we're still testing the And if you've got some different output serialization needs you can also do input deserialization For the output we use this special annotated syntax so this data frame comes from Pandas and you say this is going to be an artifact and if you don't know about artifacts that's when your parameter is a bit too big and you kind of want it to go to your S3 And in this case the function is returning a data frame so in your tests you'll say does this data frame look as expected But in Argo when it's running on the cluster it will dump it to binary format which Hera can't do automatically in this case because it doesn't know how to interpret a data frame which is a third party library So what else can Hera do You can test workflows end to end you can check execution paths and outputs you can set class defaults and pre build hooks so this really helps platform teams If you've got your organization you know your image repository needs to be mycompany com blah blah blah you can set that up and you can actually version your workflows and workflow templates so a quick aside on workflow templates We said the workflow is like a library of a workflow template is like exporting that library of functions for other people to use So with that said let's see if this works So if you want to find this code later it's on my GitHub and right now I'm going to show you it working in real life Okay So I've got some make commands set up here so we've got a build and a run so we get some requirements we build an image from it and then we run it and in this is where we're We set these global config defaults that I just mentioned so I want everyone to be using runner scripts in this repo The image is already set as this error scratch over here and then when we create the we set the namespace we get a workflow service which is just the local host make sure we don't verify SSL on the local host and then you create the So if I run or build and run we'll see it builds and then it runs and gives me a link If I click the we get a pod spinning up here and if I prove that it's really on Kubernetes it should be in here somewhere Oh it's already run It was this one So we'll see the logs inside here I said hello world We see the logs inside here It says hello world Success That's one of five All right I haven't even shown you the workflow but anyway so here we've got a script that just prints hello and then the argument that you pass in So let's say we want to do it twice We might want a and then inside the workflow we'll use that DAG  We'll set the name as something descriptive Naming is the hardest problem in programming We want each task to have a unique name so we need to pass a name here We'll pass the arguments as well so we've got an S input argument over here Can everyone see this by the way We'll do one more We'll pass world here and then we'll do it but this time we'll pass KCD Right and now we've changed Well we want to change the entry point so we were just calling the script template directly Now we want to use the DAG Let's give it a different name and we don't need these arguments anymore Right Cross your fingers It's built It's submitted Is it running There we go We've got two pods running in and proving again we're running on Kubernetes Maybe they've already run again Wow my laptop is fast today It wasn't this fast when I was practicing Yeah one says hello world one says hello KCD if we want the logs from the whole workflow we go to this tab Everything is there as expected Two down I think three to go All right what am I showing you next I'm going to add some custom input So Pylantic we need that We want the base model from it and let's say we're rating the talks that we've seen today We're not going to worry about the API We're just using standard out Let's say we need a KCD talk class which is going to inherit from base model We're going to give each talk a title which is a string and a rating of an integer We don't want this hello anymore We're going to make something new So we need this script decorator I don't need to do anything inside here but I'll just show you as well You can add things like Something goes here  All right and then inside this we're going to rate the talk with our API which is standard out Rate a talk And we have KCD talk which is that All right and then our API call looks like that Very technical I give the KCD talk title talk more rating dot rating out of five Okay and we're going to give it a better of me and I want to use it So let me just do a load of And what that might look like is in here I'll copy this out into here In this one I'm going to generate some Let's say we've done a load of number crunching We've got some S3 file paths Just use your imagination for a And with those paths we're going to tell the next task to consume them So if we build and run this one it will start generating some And this is actually random so it should be somewhere between 8 and 11 12 We've got 10  And each of these is coming from the result here So this is a special variable which reads the standard out So if you log anything in here you kind of break it So it's good for toy examples but don't use it normally And it's Zoom out I can't see Okay cool Once you've found out you might want to collect your results and bring them back in And with that we can use a fan in example which will look very similar but we'll collect the results after Similarly dumping some variables receiving them and then we need to pretend we're processing at this point Maybe we'll times them by two and then you write them out And then fan in will collect those again Let me submit that again so that we see something change Okay But the one that just ran should be finished Finishing Okay That's what it looks like You've collected all your results together and you say cool you processed all the data and let me notify the next step Cool cool And if we see in this one we generated some numbers 1 2 3 4 0 3 9 and inside we are turning a 4 into an 8 and the fan in step receives all the double numbers Cool We did some real processing Now finally I mentioned artifacts were when your parameters get too big so that's a Kubernetes limitation which is because YAML is not a great file storage system Who would have thought You want to actually move those to S3 So in this example we are using artifacts and I'm going to show you hopefully why Hera needs a script runner which simplifies everything So in this example out of the way this code is being dumped directly into the YAML So an artifact in Argoland means you put something in your container and now you want to get it out of the container and send it off to somewhere else your S3 storage And how you do that without the Hera world is you write something to a and then in the outputs you say I wrote something to this file send it on to the next thing At the moment it's just exposing it And if I run this it will write something to a file in the outputs down here Any second now there we go This output in fact looks like hello world string  Whoops inside here we're just returning a string and Hera and then Argo will handle the exporting And in the next step we're saying this is a string by the way it's an artifact so it's going to load from that And Hera will set up the YAML so that Argo understands that there's going to be artifacts coming in and out of the place So running this one we should get exactly the same workflow There we So a rather than just having another auto generated SDK It's specially written for Argo so you can be on your way happy Too long didn't read or you're falling asleep after lunch Argo workflows in Hera give
